title: describe ,ok idiom in Effective Go
body:
by **jjinux@google.com**: 
On (http://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html):

I really don't like the way "ok" is used in this code.  It seems like
if "ok" is true, then there's an error.  That seems backwards:

	if e, ok := err.(*os.PathError); ok && e.Error == os.ENOSPC {
